title: Refactor the interaction test
body:
This version removes a lot of the code repetition. It demonstrates the actions and responsibilities of the parties in exact way they take part in anonymous credential algorithms. The clarity of the test algorithm is improved substantially, so the addition of new tests to the suite should be easy.

The test suite uses new objects : Issuer, Prover and Verifier. Their implementations are self-containing: the corresponding objects hold attributes, which are in the local scope of a party only. The interface methods use minimum of parameters, which are supposed to be exchanged between parties in the network protocol.

The small improvement has been added to the Prover's make_proof() algorithm: it checks whether the proof request contains predicates and acts accordingly.

*** It could make sense to extend this test suite with more revocation-related tests, e.g. issuing several credentials and revoking them out of order of issuance or something ***

2.  Regarding long-running transactions - e.g. Faber sends Alice a PR, but won't get a response until Alice responds (potentially hours or even days) - I've assumed that the objects (Connection, Proof, etc.) can be serialized, stored (in the wallet?) and then retrieved and deserialized later, is this a correct assumption? 3.  I notice that VCX opens the wallet - this means the application can't have a previously opened wallet, because indy-sdk will throw a WalletAlreadyOpened error.  Is VCX going to deal with (proxy) all indy-sdk operations or should the VCX API take an (optional) wallet handle as a parameter?

4.  I notice VCX uses global variables to store current settings (https://github.com/ianco/indy-sdk/blob/vcx_prototype/vcx/libvcx/src/settings.rs#L238)?  Have you considered adding a context or context handle to VCX API to allow VCX to support multi-tenancy?  Currently it looks like it can only support a single wallet?

As discussed in the HIPE [0025-indy-docs-framework](https://github.com/hyperledger/indy-hipe/blob/master/text/0025-indy-docs-framework/README.md) we would like to have a centralized site for our documentation. The changes I have made are outlined in that HIPE.

title: Type safety
body:
This PR converts the json string from libindy's api to a 'real' type as soon as possible.

This makes it easier for developers who are looking e.g. at the wrappers and want to know what the actual content of a json string needs to be to find the type in the api. Otherwise developers need to search the rust files to find the type - usually at the point were the rust code de-serializes the json string.
Also this increases the type safety of the rust code by a small amount because one json string is not distinguishable from another json string.

title: Add .NET Wrapper
body:
This pull request is to add a new .NET wrapper for the SDK.  The approach has been closely modeled on the Java wrapper, although there some differences:

- Namespaces/package names have been consolidated
- Classes that generate JSON for opening pools, wallets, etc. have been skipped
- Method naming uses CamelCase and an Async suffix in line with .NET conventions. 
- Instance methods don't mention the types they refer to (e.g. CloseAsync rather than CloseWalletAsync)
- Minor differences due to language features. 

The test suite has also been replicated although several are producing anomalous results, some possibly due to IS-228.  These will require investigation and additional eyes would be appreciated.

Note that the port numbers used in Agent tests have been changed due to conflicts with the ports used by the pool nodes in my environment, but otherwise the tests are functionally the same.
